div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
REMARKS.
The general weather conditions are unchanged. The barometer is steady.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
OBSERVATIONS BY SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
For the 24 hours ending 8 a.m. Yesterday

div.p: Locusts at Duem.
A flight of locusts appeared in the vicinity of Duem last week, and caused much damage to the crops.
Crawlers Arrive.
Crawlers have appeared in large numbers at Soba in the Sudan. Efforts are being made to destroy them.
Egyptian University.
The students of Daoud Salama school at Zagazig have sent in their tenth subscription to the Egyptian University.
Quarantine Board.
The quarantine board have decided to apply the plague regulations in Egyptian ports. against arrivals from Mitylene.
Ports and Lighthouses Administration.
For two shoal beacons for the Alexandria Harbour and for one gas beacon for the Suez Creek, the tenders of Mr. D. Chartrain, Cairo, have been accepted.
The Chauffeurs Strike.
The strike of chauffeurs attached to the Cairo auto-garage has ended by the employ ment by the firm of an entirely new staff from among private chauffeurs.
Alexandria's Revenue.
During the last 9 months the Alexandria Municipality has received in rentals from the money changing stalls and outside spaces occupied by the various cafés a sum of L.E. 8,000.
Hama-Aleppo Line.

A Commission of engineers including Colonel Zia Bey, of the Technical Board at the Ministry of Public Works, is arriving shortly in Syria from Constantinople to take delivery of the Hama-Aleppo railway.
Measures for Public Security.

The Government has decided that three English non-commissioned officers, drawn from the Army of Occupation, shall be attached to the more important caracols with the object of learning the duties of Mamour.
Benghazi Harbour.

The Ottoman Authorities have at last decided in principle to continue the harbour works at Benghazi which have been suspended for some time. The Ministry of Public Works will send an engineer to Benghazi to report on the works.
Mousky Safe-Breaking.

Two of the Greeks alleged to have been concerned in the recent safe breaking case in the Mousky Market were brought up for trial to day, when one was sentenced to one year's imprisonment, and the other was aquitted. The former has given notice of appeal, but is detained a prisoner.
Memorial to Sir B. Baker.

It has been decided to place a tablet to the memory of the late Sir Benjamin Baker, the famous engineer, in the church at Pangbourne, where his country residence was situated. The work has been entrusted to Mr. E. Whitney- Smith, who executed the fountain which was unveiled recently at the Baltic.
A Mysterious Disappearance.

Notices appear all over the town offering a reward of P.T. 1,000 for a clue to the discovery of Mr. Edgard Eggert, an employé of Messrs. Boehme and Anderer, Cairo, who disappeared. on the 29th of August. The disappearance is attributed to a crime or to suicide, and it has been stated that the young man was last bserved in a Zeitoun pharmacy on the evening of his disappearance.
Syrian Immigration.

A number of Syrians have of late been arriving in Jamaica, and these together with the influx of Chinese have led a serious section of the press to urge the Government to prevent their landing as being detrimental to the local traders. The City Council of Kingston has adopted a resolution calling upon the Govern ment to amend the pauper alien immigration law to prohibit the entrance of undesirable foreigners who seek trade to the ruin of natives and other subjects of the King.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL
div.p: Fifty pupils have been admitted to the English section of the Khedivial Law School and 28 applications refused. All candidates for the French section were accepted.

div.head: RUMOURED BANK LOSSES
div.p: DISCREDITED IN MANCHESTER
(Gazette's Special Service.)
London, Tuesday.

The rumours that a Manchester Bank has incurred losses amounting to £750,000 in connection with the Egyptian trade failures is totally discredited in the best banking circles in Manchester where the report is considered as grossly exaggerated.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: A Council of Ministers was held yesterday morning at Ras-El-Tin palace under the presidency of the Khedive when the following were approved:
1. The appointment of Mr. Paul Harvey Financial Adviser to the Government from the 9th instant.

2. A proposal to confer the "Mirmiran" rank (which carries with it the title of Pasha) on August Bey Adibe, Director General of State Accounts, and the Sanieh rank on Ahmed Bey Fathy, ex-Judge of the Native Tribunals, who was lately placed on pension.
3. To declare of public utility the works necessitated by the raising of the Assouan dam, and the diversion created at Zefta for the conveyance of water from the Nile to that town.
4. To cancel the second paragraph of the Khedivial decree of 23rd January 1905 relating to the enlargement of 3 cemeteries in Behera province.
5. The collection of a tax of L.E. 1 for every licence issued for the digging of earth from canal-banks and drains.
6. The appointment of Fox Bey Adminis trative Director; Goldenstein Bey General Secretary and Salib Bey Ikladius Chief Inspector to the Postal Administration at L.E. 65 per month each.
7. The opening of a credit of L.E. 34,000 to the Ports and Lighthouses Administration of the construction of quays for the discharge of timber.
8. The opening of a credit of L.E. 18,000 to the Ministry of Public Works for the construction of a new wing to the building of the Finance Ministry.

div.head: SUNDAY CLOSING.
div.p: RESISTANCE OF SHOP-OWNERS. The following letter has been addressed to the Governor of Alexandria by Mr. Georges Rublié, President of the International Society of Employés in Alexandria:-

Excellency-We take the very great liberty of drawing your attention to the fact that, doubtless in order to force us to resistance, the shops which remained closed last Sunday for fear of the demonstration, re-opened today with the object of setting an undesirable example and of exciting the employés. In spite of such conduct we shall always continue to keep the promises which we have undertaken with you and this will prove to you the good faith which guides us in all our acts. We have the honour to be, Excellency, your devoted servants.
Alexandria, October 6.
Etc Ete.

We are glad to recognise the wise manner in which the committee of the Society have decided to resist the demands of the shopowners that work should be carried on on Sundays and the loyalty with which they are supported by the members. At the demonstration held on the 29th ult. the Governor thanked the meeting for the orderliness which they had maintained, but asked that there should be no further demonstrations, promising at the same time that he would give full attention to their interests. This demand of the Governor, the Society have agreed to regard in spirit and in letter, and we trust that the shop-owners will adopt the same fair spirit of fight as is being shown by their employés.

div.head: RAILSULI'S DEMANDS.
div.p: REDUCTION IN RANSOM.

London, 7th October. The "Morning Post" learns from Tangier that El Raisuli has reduced the terms of Sir H. Maclean's release to British protection for himself and family and a ransom of £30,000. The British Government is prepared to grant the protection and to advance the ransom on the Sultan's guarantee to refund the (Reuter) Last week the British Government refused to comply with Raisuli's demand for £70,000.. In a telegram despatched from Tangier on the 1st inst. Mr. Maxwell, the special correspondent, of the "Daily Mail" wired :-
amount.

El Dowdie, the scribe and representative of Raisuli, cannot understand the reluctance of the British authorities, and insists on the payment of this sum. The Sultan can pay. He has sent. to Europe jewels worth £1,000,000. It is useless to tell him that they have been valued at a quarter of that amount. You cannot argue with El Dowdie, who smilingly tells our Minister that all Moors are robbers. He meets your arguments with a shake of the head and
says: "Maclean is like a tig on the tree. Many people put forth their hands and touch it, but perhaps the fig is not ripe."
Raisuli, no doubt, will moderate his terms, and accept half in consideration of British protection for himself and his family.

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS.
div.p: THE EGYPTIAN LIBERALS
L

The address, which Mohamed Bey Wahid, the chief of the new Egyptian Liberal party, recently sent to Sir Edward Grey, is much commented on in the home newspapers, who style the Bey's following as the "loyal party." On the other hand Moustapha Pasha Kamel's letter to Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has hardly been noticed, as it is considered so ridiculously extravagant as to be undeserving of serious comment. The "Globe" remarks in regard to Mohamed Bey Wahid's address:-

A recent manifesto from the loyal party in Egypt, as well as several declarations of those Indians who have not been misled by the seditious utterances of babu orators and writers, should give pause to those at home who are too ready to credit anything that tells against British methods of rule among non- European races. It is perhaps too often forgotten that there is little to be gained by open professions of loyalty, whereas much profit and kudos are obtained by the agitator who plays his cards dexterously. Under the mask of disinterested patriotism, the latter can serve his own ends without much risk of being called to account by an easy-going Government; but so long as he feathers his own nest, it is of little consequence to him what befalls the people. A prosecution often fails, and he can then pose as a martyr without any cost to himself: it is only prison which he dreads, and that, under a regime favourable to free speech and a free Press, is an unlikely enough contingency. The loyalists, on the other hand, only give vent to their feelings when some particular reason urges them to do so; and they have small thanks for their pains. They are covered with vituperation in the factious native journals, and too often they are assailed by that section of the English Press which only believes in free speech so long as it is consistently anti-British in tone, and which will swallow anything, so long as it is a slander on the British name and an indictment of British methods.
KAMEL & CAMPBELL-BANNERMAN.
Great annoyance is of course felt at the way in which Kamel's letter to the Premier has fallen so flat. The London correspondent of "Les Pyramides," of Cairo, writes to his journal:
"There are none so deaf"-you know the
rest.

I was reminded of this adage by the fashion in which the English press received the publication in the Paris press of Moustafa Pasha Kamel's letter to Sir Henry Campbell Bannermann. The English press said nothing about it. At most one or two journals spoke of an "extravagant letter," which an Egyptian had addressed to the British Prime Minister. It is simple but it is also essentially practical and certainly affective.

For the English ignore absolutely the contents of the letter in question. In this country there is an admirable conspiracy of silence in respect of disagreeable things which it is not desirable to notice. It is the history of Nelson applying his telescope to his blind eye in order not to see the signal which he had resolved to disobey.
The English even our confrères of the British press-are not all Nelsons, but they can all be blind when it suits their purpose. That is how no one here knows about the letter of Moustafa Pasha Kamel.

It is maladroit. For if the letter be "extravagant," there should be no objection to letting its contents be known; if on the other hand, it has any importance whatever, to ignore it, merely enhances that importance. Whence it appears the English press has committed a blunder.

I know that you will tell me that their blunders are beyond count. It is none the less a blunder. Only their blunder is part of the British tactics which consist in affirming with an apparent conviction, whose sincerity is in- contestable, that there is no longer any Egyptian Question. It amounts to saying there is no longer any Egypt. Now, there is an ryptian question, which will exist as long a the Egyptians and Egyptare governed by foreigners. And this fact will be perceived by the Enlish with profound astonishment to-morrow, n a year, in five years, in ten years.-What! We were told there was no longer any Egyptian Question-But my good people there is, nly you take your desires for realities-whance certain periodical disappointments.
FRENCH OPINION.

Commenting on Moustafa Kamel's en letter, the "Temps" says that while tere cannot be two opinions as to the work acomplished by England in Egypt, Lord Cromerras wanting in political tact, and his farsightedness was impaired by prejudice, as is proved by the Denshawi affair.
y

But who can forget that it is precisely her capacity for evolution which is Great Briton's imperishable glory in Colonial history should not Egypt benefit thereby, like Cana, Australia, even the Transvaal! In order to attain thereto Egyptians must carefully avoid creating the impression in London that they are in revolt. But if they confine themselves to the demand for self-government they canno be held to blame. The necessary virtues for ne solution of the question are correctness and moderation on the Egyptian side, and on the English liberalism and good grace.
THE PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
The members of the newly formed polival party, "The Party of the People," held a meet ing last Sunday at the offices of the newspeter, "El Gueridah," in order to draw up aro
A
gramme and to decide on what steps should be taken in order to make their plan of campaign effective.
This party has no connections with Mousta pha Pasha Kamel or the aims of "Al Dewa."
THE PATRIOT ARRIVES.
The "Egyptian Standard" gives a protentous description of the "Egyptian Patriot's" arrival in Cairo yesterday, from which we extract the fallowing :-
"Upon the arrival of the train a cry from at least four thousand throats went up : "Long live Moustafa Kamel Pasha! Long live the leader of the movement ! Long live the "Standards!"

The dense crowd literally bore the leader of the Egyptian National Movement from the train to his carriage. Cheers, resounded all the way. At the foot of his carriage the Pasha stood still a moment.: Silence: immediately ensued. Then the Pasha spoke a few stirring words:
Say only Long live Egypt and Liberty And a responsive cheer was the immediate answer."

"We have seen many popular demonstrations -even such as have been announced and advertised. But such a spontaneous outburst of enthusiasm as that witnessed by us last night at the railway station is exceptional. It is epoch-making."

div.head: A MISCHIEVOUS RUMOUR.
div.p: Our trilingual nationalist Cairo contemporary gives prominence to, an alleged rumour that "a high functionary in the Ministry of Justice has used his authority tuching the independence of the Bar to their advantage and made threats with a view to executing his will." The rumour is said by our contemporary to have emanated from the intruders' satel lites." Knowing, as we and all our readers do, the intolerance with which the intruders (Syrians) are regarded by Kamel Pasha and his clique, and bearing in mind the vehement and unjust (we might almost term them fanar tical) tirades against the Syrians by so-called nationalists we are inclined to temper the allegation with several grains of salt. Be that as it may, however, we are authorised to state that the Ministry of Justice had never heard of such a ramour and to state, now that it has been circulated by "Al Lewa", that it is absolutely groundless.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: THE KHEDIVE'S PATRONAGE.

His Highness the Khedive has graciously consented to accord his patronage to the fifth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club to be held at Gabbary on Saturday next, commencing at 2:45 p.m.

The number of entries for the various events is more numerous than ever and we are promised a succession of close contests. Arrangements are now nearly completed and are as perfect as in former years, and the comfortable accommodation of the large number of spectators anticipated has been well provided for. Faller details will be given in our issue of Friday, but in the meantime we might mention but in the that the events will include the following:- 60 Yards Seniors Handicap for "Sirdar" Medal; Plunging Championship; Polo Match; Tag-of-War; Diving Championships; Veterans' Race; Walking the Pole; Blindfold Race; Obstacle Race; Juniors' Race; Cock Fighting; Bobbing for Corks; and a 360 Yards Team Race in which the following clubs will compete :- Alexandria Rowing Club, Club Internazionale Canottieri, Club Nautique Français, Deutscher Sportverein. An orchestra will play selections during the afternoon.

div.head: BRITISH RIFLE CLUB (ALEX.)
div.p: Members are informed that owing to the Alexandria Swimming Club Aquatic Sports taking place next Saturday, the British Rifle Club will not shoot on that day.

div.head: CRIME IN EGYPT.
div.p: NATIVE PRESS OPINIONS.
(From Al Watan.)

For a long time it was held by many persons that England desired to see permanent insecurity in Egypt for some sinister design. They argued that England wished to create reasons for perpetuating the occupation or for finding fault with the Egyptian officials and replacing them by young men from England. The supposition was false, of course, but it cannot be denied that the continued inaction and, apparent incapacity of certain officials in matters of public security have furnished food for mis- understanding and greatly damaged the cause of reform.

It appears now that a move has at last been made in the right direction. The Ministry of Justice deputed some time ago one of its most intelligent and capable Inspectors to direct the Parquet affairs in one of the Delta provinces which had become notorious for an alarming increase of crime in its villages. That gentleman spent some months in studying cases past and present and in ascertaining the cause of the said increase in the number of crimes. After long study and research he seems to have come to the conclusion published repeatedly by us during these months. He found that the criminally-inclined section of the populace had grown audacious and perpetrated offences ad libitum because the police was unable to arrest them, and the Parquet could not prove their guilt, both matters of moment to which we have always referred with regret. The able inspector is said to have submitted an elaborate report to the Ministry of Justice upon the termination of his mission laying stress upon the fact that the Parquet as now constituted was unable to cope with the growing evil of crime. He found that the members of the Parquet are generally of a class altogether unfitted for the most delicate work entrusted to them. They are young, inexperienced, and in the majority of cases addicted to amusements and pastimes. They pass their nights in ques tionable occupations and come in the morning to investigate the most difficult mysteries in a state of mind hardly equal to the onerous task. Thus, with their proverbial, lack of ex- perience and with dilapidated energies they set to work in a most unseemly manner ending in almost every case with failure. Naturally they have to trust to others for detecting criminals and they embrace the views of the police officials, Mamoors, or Omidehs who furnish them with the details of the preliminary inquiry in a distorted, dishonest, and ofalse shape suiting their many ends and designs. The Parquet official, therefore, is a merertobl in the hands of interested and unscrupulous employés who help to hide the facts of criminal incidents for a consideration, and the result is that most of our criminala remain abelarge, officially unknown and openly unpunished for their crimes. Is it wonderful that crime is ever increasing when the important work of detecting crime and denouncing the real criminals is entrusted to such hands?

We believe that this report will conduce to the reform for which we have been long clamouring and make a sweeping change in the vicious system and inefficient personnel of public security work in Egypt.

div.head: THE EVE OF RAMADAN
div.p: Ruya, the eve of the fast of Ramadan, was duly celebrated yesterday afternoon in Cairo when a huge crowd assembled in the vicinity of the Gouvernorat to witness the procession which started from there for the Religious Courts where the final ceremony of the day takes place, when in the presence of the notables of the Mohammedan world in the Capital, witnesses formally declare that the new moon has been seen, and the fast of Ramadan is pronounced to have begun.

The fifth Battalion of Infantry were in readiness at the Gouvernorat at about three o'clock, but it was not until quite four o'clock that the signal for the start was given, and the troops, led by the Cavalry band, streamed out to the streets, to where the crowds were eagerly awaiting their arrival.

During the march the procession was considerably augmented by the arrival of native horsemen, each little cavalcade having its own particular band to lead it, and in consequence progress was somewhat slower than sit might otherwise have been, and it was five o'clock by the time that the troops arrived at the Courts.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN BOLTON.
div.p: Mr. W. Tattersall, writing in the "Financier" last week on the cotton position in Lancashire,
says:

"Yarns made from Egyptian cotton in the Bolton district and South Lancashire are deeply sold in practically, all counts and.qualities. Business, however, is not easily arranged. Not only is price against, buyers, but a long time has to be given for the completion of orders now being booked. Fine numbers in combed descriptions are, perhaps, more deeply sold than ever before in the history of the trade. Engagements are also extensive in card- ed counts. The business coming round bas not been important, but spinners do not seek fresh orders, and many, producers are independent and, indifferent sellers. Considerable inconvenience is being caused by spinners being behind contract time with deliveries."

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner: Rameses" sailed from Liverpool on Saturday last, and is due here about the 19th inst, with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Boutros Pasha bali arrived here this morning from Marseilles.
Mr. P. W. Machell and Lord Edward Cecil both had lengthy interviews with the Governor of Cairo yesterday morning.
Hassan Pasha Mohsen and his family are arriving at Alexandria from Europe on Monday next.
Ahmed Be Mohsen and his wife and family arrived at Axandria, from Gopatantinople by the Khedivia S.S. "Ismailia.'"
Lady Mellwraith, after spending the summer in England, will leave London late in October to rejoin Sir Malcolm Melwraith in Cairo.
Sir Stephen Mackenzie will revisit Egypt again this winter.

The Earl and Countess of Yarborough and family left Braklesby Hall last week for London, en route for Lucerne, the Italian Lakes, Egypt, and possibly Japan. Their stay abroad will probably extend over mine months.
The Sultan has conferred the Liakat gold medal on Mohamed Bey Izzet, Turkish Chef du Bureau to the Khedive.
Mr. Charles Beyerlé, Managing Director of the Credit Foncier Egyptien, is arriving from Europe on the 15th inst.
The sad news comes from Marseilles of the death of Bimbashi Lowther, Artillery, E. A., who was returning to Egypt from leave.

The latest London papers announce the death last week of Major Robert Adeane Barlow in the Poor Law Infirmary at Enfield. He obtained employment in the Abyssinian army, and was finally captured by followers of the Mahdi and was imprisoned in Egypt, his capture and subsequent treatment being the subject of questions raised in the House of Commons, besides some judicial proceedings in Egypt for illegal imprisonment. I stopp renasit es
re

During about the last twenty-five years Major Barlow lived in and around Enfield, where, during the early "eighties" her was a conspicuous figure. When the late General Gordon set out on his ill-fated journey to Khartoum the Major, to whom he was personally known, applied in vain for permission to accompany him. telny od sta

Captain Edward St, George Lowther, Royal Field Artillery, whose death at Marseilles on the 24th ult. is reported, had served in the Egyptian army since July, 1905. He was the eldest surviving son of Colonel W. G. Lowther, of Shrigley park, Macclesfield, Cheshire, and joined the Royal Artillery, from the Militia as a second lieutenant in December 1898, being promoted to lieutenant in February, 1901, He served in the South African War of 1899-1900, and was severely, wounded, being mentioned for his services in the London Gazette of September 10, 1901, and receiving, the Queen's medal with three clasps. Froin March, 1902,- to November 1908, he was employed with the West African Frontier Force, His commission as captain was dated September 21, 1906, and he would only have attained the age of 29 in December next,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: . (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Malgré las reprise constatée au Stook Exchange, sur nos valeurs dirigeantes, celles-ci n'ont pas réussi à rentrer en faveur chez nous. Elles sont en général négligées et de ce fait on peut considérer leur légère plus-value comme purement nominale, excepté en Agricole qui a donné lieu à quelques rares transactions. Les titres d'ordre inférieur n'ont pas été mieux partagés. A part une ombre d'attention accordée aux Estates, Delta Land et Comptoir, on a été sur tout le reste silencieux. Bref, les transeotions dans leur ensemble se sont encore raré. fiées. Toute l'activité, et elle a été limitée, s'est concentrée sur les Nongovich Hotels et Cassa di Sconto. Plusieurs arguent de ce manque d'affaires que les vendeurs, dans l'attente de plus hauts prix, se tiennent sur l'expectative. Quoi qu'il en soit, le calme prédomine. Au Caire tout le mouvement porte, parait-il, sur les titres patronnés par la maison De Vries et Boutigny.
L'Agricole progresse de 8 1/4 à 8 5/16, la National Bank de 21 7/8 à 22, la Daïra de 13 1/2 à 13 5/8, et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 301 à 303 l'ancienne et de 254 à 254 1/2 la nouvelle.

En hausse également la Béhéra de 21 1/8 à à 21 1/2 et les Nungovich Hotels de 17 à 17 3/4, soit une plus value respective de 3/8 et 3/4 de livre. L'Union Foncière gagne aussi 1/16 à 4 13/16 à la suite d'une demande.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, la Cassa di Sconto avance de 44 1/2 à 46 1/2, le Comptoir de 2 3/4 l'ancienne, 2 13/16 la nouvelle et 1 7/8 la fondateur, à 2 13/16, 2 7/8 et 1 15/16 respectivement, les Cotton Ginners de 1 1/4 à 1 11/32 ; seule l'Helonan rétrograde de 7/32 à 8/16.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement à signaler.

On voit par les quelques lignes qui précè. dent que les fluctuations ne sont pas nombreages, ni importantes et qu'elles indiquent généralement une avance, conséquence en par. tie de la reprise constatée à Londres et en partie de l'extrême réserve de la spéculation locale. Les affaires ont été presque nulles, comme nous venons de le dire. Que ce soit fante de vendears, comme disent les ung, ou faute d'acheteurs, comme le prétendent les autres, l'avenir le dira. En ce qui concerne les Nungovich, la demande provient du Caire. Comme ce titre a subi naguère des fluctuations fantastiques, on craint, dit-on, de s'y engager. Ce qui semble acquis c'est que les détenteurs ou aoquéreurs sérieux se tiennent encore à l'écart du marché et il faut attendre leur entrée en scène pour se faire une idée de la tournure que prendront les affaires. Jusqu'à présent, ainsi que nous l'avons déjà dit, il s'agit plutôt de spéculation à courte échéance.

div.head: Circulaire A. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Lundi 7 Octobre. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné invarié à 4 pour cent.

Au Stock-Excbange, le Consolidé a haussé hier de 1/8 à 83 1/4. L'Unifiée a gardé son avance de vendredi à 102 1/4. La National Bank s'est inserite invariée à 22. La Daïra, en nouvelle réaction, est revenue à 13 1/2. L'Agricole s'est raffermie à 8 1/4. La Delta Light & fléchi de 1/8 à 10 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien qui vendredi avait gagné 2 francs a perdu i frano samedi à 699.La Banque d'Athènes a été ramenée à 112. Les Lots Turcs ont accentué leur avance à 172.

Ici, le marchó a été excellent comme début de semaine, et la fermeté de Londres aidant, I il a conservé aisément ses bonnes dispositions sur presque toutes les valeurs. Les plus-values sont disséminées un peu dans tous les compartiments, sauf dans celui des Banques, qui a été très calme. La séance a été, à peu de choses près, consacrée presque entièrement aux valeurs patronnées par notre firme, ainsi qu'à quelques autres titres. A de certains moments, l'avimation très nourrie rappelait, sans perdre à la comparaison, les séances du dernier biver, et si l'on songe que la période des affaires n'a en somme pas encore commencé, on se convaincra que les gens avisés étaient ceux qui, au plus fort de la crise, ne désespéraient pas de l'Egypte.
Nous verrons certainement mieux plus avant dans la saison.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na tional Bank revient à 22. L'Agricole est moins ferme à 8 1/4-5/16. C'est là un simple effet de l'arrêt de leur hausse à Londres. La Banque d'Orient mollit à 120.

La Delta Light bien que recherchée s'inscrit invariée à 10 1/2. Les Jouissances Faux du Caire haussent à 196-197. La Daïra Sanieh se tasse à 13 9/16-5/8. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est en gain à 694 ainsi que l'obligation ancienne à 302-303. L'Allotment est plus faible à 2 3/8. L'Enterprise and Development recule à 8 7/8 et sa part à 12 1/2. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont occupé à elles seules toute la séance, l'action a haussé à 2 7/8 et les parts après des Agotnations très vives, quí les avaient portées à P.T. 70' ont olóturé P.T. 60. L'Union Foncière a fléchi å 4 578. I/Express Nile Steamers fondateur a haussé jusqu'à P.T. 75 pour finir à PT. 70: D'anglo-American Nile est en bonne tendance à 2 1/2.9/16. div.head: FRANCE AND SPAIN
div.p: THE MOORISH COAST.
MADRID, October 7.
Spain, apparently yielding to public opinion has joined the French measures to preven contraband of arms on the Moorish coast, to which she at first refused adhesion. (Reuter) CASABLANCA, October 7.

Much friction exists between General Drude and the Spanish commander regarding the policing of the suburbs of Casablanca. The Algeciras convention entrusted this to Spain but circumstances have arisen requiring Ge neral Drude to occupy these districts in the interests of pacification. The Spanish officer although not possessing the necessary troops refuses to recognise the circumstances of the
recogn P
case.
(Reuter)
RABAT, October 7. M. Regnault and General Liautey have arrived but the bar is impassable owing to heavy weather.
(Reuter

div.head: AUSTRIA AND HUNGARY.
div.p: THE AUSGLEICH.
VIENNA, October 7.

The chief change in the new Austro-Hungarian Ausgleich is the substitution of a commercial treaty for the customs union. It is understood that Hungary's contributions to the common expenses will be increased by 1%. (Reuter)
VIENNA, October 7.

The details of the Ausgleich have not been stated but the greatest satisfaction is felt both in Austria and Hungary regarding the friendly termination for a decade of the struggle which lasted since 1897. The consensus of opinion is that the Emperor largely contributed towards the agreement. (Reuter)
BUDAPEST, October 7.
M. Kossuth declared that the compromises satisfied the two nations.
(Havas)

div.head: THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
div.p: OBLIGATORY ARBITRATION.
THE HAGUE, October 7.

The Arbitration Committee of the Convention on Saturday exhaustively debated and adopted by 30 votes to 6 the principle of obligatory arbitration on certain specific subjects set forth in the general convention. The minority consisted of Germany, Austria, Rumania, Greece, Turkey, and China. Four countries abstained from voting, including Japan. (Reuter)
THE CUAMATAS DEFEATED.
CHIEF KRAAL CAPTURED.
LISBONE, October 7.
The Portuguese troops have decisively defeated the Cuamatas and have captured the chief kraal. They have lost 2 killed and 14 wounded. (Reuter)
U. S. A. AND JAPAN.
COOLIE EMIGRATION.
LONDON, October 7.

The "Morning Post" learns from Washington on good authority that the principal reason of Mr. Taft's visit to Japan is to inform the latter that unless the emigration of coolies to America is checked the Exclusion Bill will be introduced to Congress during the coming session.
(Renter)
MACEDONIA.
MURDER OF GREEKS.
SALONIKA, October 7.

A Bulgarian band of 200 attacked the Greek village of Negovani in the vilayet of Monastir. Details of the occurrence are lacking. Another Bulgarian band killed four Greeks working in vineyards near Serres.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE ABYSSINIAN MISSION.
div.p: RECEPTION BY THE POPE.
ROME, October 7. The Pope has received the Abyssinian mis sion which has aroused great interest at the Vatican.
(Reuter

div.head: COTTON HANDLERS UNION
div.p: 8,000 MEMBERS STRIKE.
NEW ORLEANS, October 7.
8,000 members of the Cotton Handlers Union here have struck, thus stopping all shipments of cotton.
(Reuter
OE

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR.
div.p: LETTER TO THE "TEMPS."
PARIS, October 7.
In a letter addressed to the "Temps" Mr. Lambert, ex-director of the Khedivial Law School, explains his disagreement with Mr. Dunlop.
(Havas

div.head: GERMAN DIPLOMATIC
div.p: SERVICE.
BERLIN, October 7.

The Foreign Secretary, Herr Tschirschky, has been appointed Ambassador at Vienna in place of Count de Wedel who becomes Gover nor of Alsace-Lorraine in succession to Prince Hohenlohe who has resigned on the ground of age. Herr W. de Schoen at. St. Petersburg replaces Herr Tschirschky. (Reuter)
BERLIN, October 7.
M. Schoen replaces M. De Tchirsky who has been appointed Ambassador at Vienna.
(Havas)
GREAT BRITAIN'S TRADE.
LONDON, October 7
The imports for the month of September shews an increase of £281,441 and the exports £4,631,167 over the same period last year.
(Reuter)

div.head: PARIS COUNCILLORS IN LONDON.
div.p: LONDON, October 7.
The Paris Councillors have been entertained at a banquet at the Guildhall.
(Reuter)
THE ARGELIER CASE.
MONTPELLIER, October 7.
The Argelier case will come before the court of assizes.
(Havas)

div.head: PLAGUE AT ORAN.
div.p: ORAN, October 7.
There have been two fresh cases of plague here. The granting of pratique has been post
poned.
(Reuter)
ORAN, October 7. Two new cases of plague have been notified.
(Havas)
GAS STRIKE` IN ITALY.
ROME, October 7.
The workmen of the gas-works at Milan, Genoa, and Sanpierdarena are on strike.
(Havas)
GRAND DUKE OF BADEN'S FUNERAL.
CARLSRUHE, October 7. The Kaiser and the Imperial Princes were present at the funeral of the Grand Duke.
(Havas)

EGYPT'S TRADE.
GUNNY BAGS

The statistics, of the imports of sacks into Egypt during the past five years, clearly show the monopoly which India practically is has of the trade, and also the heavy increase the in price which has recently taken place in er) the article.

With regard to the heavy drop in the re turns for 1906 compared with those of the N. previous year we may mention that in 1905 a big cotton crop was expected and heavy shipments of bags made accordingly. The hopes of the merchants were not realized, and large stocks were consequently carried forward.
The whole of the jute supply for Calcutta, ers Dundee, and elsewhere comes from the Bengal all district, which is the only country where jute r) has so far been successfully grown. The better

qualities of fibre for making flour and cement bags (and also for use in various other trades) go to Dundee, whilst, so far as Egypt is concerned, the cheaper varieties are worked up in Calcutta into sacks for transporting cotton, cotton seed, grain and onions. Thus from the Egyptian merchant's point of view Dundee and Calcutta can hardly be said to be competitors, Ir. since, broadly speaking, the articles made in aw each place are quite different.
Cotton and Grain Bags.

The ordinary 3 lbs sack used especially for wheat, barley, and other kinds of grain, the 5 lbs cotton seed bag and the 3 and 4 lbs cotton sacks, all made in India, are the ones principally found on this market. The two former are 60 in: by 30 in, and have 6

porter and 8 shot. The 3 lbs and 3 lbs y cotton sacks are 85 by 45, are 85 by 45, contain 9 in porter and 10 shot, and are generally made er from a certain quality of jute known as ce Hessian cloth. The tendency, at any rate of amongst Europeans, is to use the heavier g sack, as it is found that the additional cost
e

is compensated by the better wearing quali ties. On the other hand, a factor in favour of the lighter bag is the keenness of the native to change the heavier sack for an inferior one, it he has the slightest opportunity of doing so.
Flour Bags.
These bags which, of course, must have a much closer texture than the ones for cotton

or cotton seed-in point of fact, a certain er amount of retaining material is worked into ts the fibre in order to prevent the flour passing through the meshes-are almost entirely imported from Dundee, as the Calcutta mills lack the skilled labour for making a high grade flour bag, and, further, their machinery is not adapted for this kind of work. The shipments, however, are only small as the bags in which the flour arrives are subsequently washed and then used again after milling.
d Sugar Bags.

The "Daira" sugar bags containing 6 porter and 8 shot, measuring 29 by 42 1/2, and weighing 2 1/2 lbs are those commonly used in the work of carrying the sugar from the factory to the refinery. It is estimated that t about 600,000 of these bags reach Egypt ) annually.
Onion Bags.

Various qualities weighing 10, 11, and 12 } ounces are employed in the onion trade here. The bags are of Indian manufacture, and are usually 9 porter and 10 shot, the size being 40 by 24. The imports are about 2,000,000 a year.
Special Sized Bags
The orders for bags of special sizes or weights usually find their way to Dundee since, for 1. obvious reasons the Indian mills usually con
fire themselves to stock sizes.

As a matter of possible interest to Dundee mill owners, we may say that the freight from Calcutta and Suez runs about 25/- and 30/- a ton of 50 cubic feet, whilst the railway charges from the latter port to Alexandria or the Delta villages are 5 paras for each 5 lbs grain bag, 3 paras for each 3 lbs bag, and 3 paras for each 3 lbs bag. (40 paras equal two pence half penny).
There is not a large trade between Egypt and the Sudan, though a certain quantity go up to Khartoum in connection with the gum industry.

Under the heading "Bags for the Egyptian Army-Supplies from India" the following somewhat ominous announcement recently appeared in the "Indian Trade Journal," which is an official organ of the Indian Government.

"In our issue of 19th July 1906, we recorded the steps taken by this Department to obtain for Indian manufacturers of te goods a share in certain Egyptian Government contracts that had been notified in he Board of Trade Journal. Samples of he flour sacks then in question and also of gin sacks subsequently wanted were procured from the Department of Supplies of he Egyptian Army and were placed on exhibit on at the office of this Department, and attention was drawn to these from time to time." (To be concluded).
(British Chamber of Commerce Bulletin

div.head: MACEDONIAN FINANCIAL COMMISSION.
div.p: MR. R.W. GRAVES'S IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT

The appointment of Mr. R.W. Graves, his Majesty's Consul General at Salonica, to be the British Delegate on the Financial Commission for Macedonia has given general satisfaction, says the "Times" correspondent at Constantinople. It is felt that his knowledge of the country and the language will strengthen the commission at a point at which it has hitherto been deplorably weak, for, strange as it may appear, none of the other members is able to read a Turkish document or to speak to a Turkish official in his own tongue. As it is now proposed to charge the commission with the task of controlling the judicial administration, it is high time that at any rate one of the members should be capable of reading the "procès verbal" of a trial without having to get it translated and of conversing with a Turkish Judge or witness without the assistance of an interpreter. Mr. Graves, moreover, has served for many years in Balgaria, and knows the language and people of that country as intimately as he knows Turkish and the Turks and his long experience of Balkan affairs will be of use in other ways. The fact that the Powers hitherto have attached so little importance to qualifications of this kind in selecting agents to carry out reforms is one of the main reasons why public opinion in Constantinople has been so sceptical as to their sincerity. Apart from such considerations, everybody who knows Mr. Graves is delighted with this proof that the excellent work which he has done during more than 20 years in the Levant Consular service is appreciated by the Government, especially as that service has not been very generously treated in the past.

div.head: THE PARTITION OF TURKEY.
div.p: An old diplomatist, writing in the "Rhenish Westphalian Gazette," considers that there must be some deeper reason for the great change in Russian policy manifested in the new Convention with England than appears on the surface and suggests that it is to be found in the partition of Turkey.

England, he says, has not reckoned in vain with the weakly and pacific nature of the Emperor of Russia and with the petticoat politics that dominate at St. Petersburg, "to which influences alone is due the victory over GermanRussian policy in foreign affairs." With the aid of the present policy in St. Petersburg he contends that England has succeeded in concluding what, for Russia, is an unnatural agreement, and that it will continue to direct Russian policy in wrong paths. A bait must, however, he asserts, have been offered, even to impotent Russia to induce her to desist from crossing British plans in the Indian Ocean, and rumour says that the bait is Turkey.

The question of the partition of Turkey must come up on the death of the present Sultan, and when this event occurs Russia is to be given a free hand in the Balkans and Asia Minor, while Persia and the Euphrates countries are to fall to England. That England and Russia have come to a secret understanding on the subject of Turkey is, in the opinion of the old diplomatist, more clear from the fact that all mention of this subject is avoided in the Convention. He concludes with a prophecy that this understanding between England and Russia will not long endure.

div.head: PRICE OF WHISKY.
div.p: The Distillers Company (Limited), which is the largest whisky-producing concern in the world intimate that their whiskies are increased in price 2d per gallon to Scottish and English distillers, and 3d per gallon to Irish distillers, all 25 O.P. gallon. The Distillers Company practically control the production of the grain whisky of the United Kingdom, and their products are almost entirely used for blending purposes. That is to say, grain whisky passes to large blenders for blending with the Highland and Lowland malt whiskies. The movement, therefore, by the large producers of grain whisky must have far-reaching effects.

Already the Highland and the Island distillers have had conferences, with the object of increasing the price of whisky, and this action by the Distillers Company is sure to be followed by an all-round advance. The retail price will be unaffected. The reason of the rise is the increased cost of fuel and barley.

div.head: LORD MINTO AND INDIAN MOSLEMS
div.p: The Bombay delegates to the deputation of prominent Mahomedans which waited upon Lord Minto last October have approached Nawab Mohsin-ul-Mulk, the hon. secretary of the deputation, requesting him, in the absence from the country of the president, the Aga Khan, to take steps for conveying to the Viceroy the gratitude of the deputation, on behalf of the Indian Moslems, for the constitutional reforms adumbrated in the recently-published letter to the local administrations. They regard the document as a sincere and timely attempt on, the part of Government to respond to the practical ideals of liberty and progress which are stirring the natural leaders of all classes and sects in this country, provision being made for due and adequate protection of the great Mahomedan minority India. Upon the ultimate satisfactory settlement of the details of the proposed reforms depends not a little the fate of his Majesty's Indian Mahomedan subjects, and these details should be carefully studied by the leaders of the community in each of the provinces. Meanwhile, they should express their gratitude to Lord Minto for the due fulfilment of the promises he made to the deputation. At a critical period in the history of British India, his Excellency had, on his own initiative, set forth a scheme of reforms which would in the main command the approval of all moderate and sober leaders of public opinion in India; and there could be no doubt that his name would be enrolled with those distinguished sons of Great Britain who had from time to time helped to consolidate the foundations of British rule in India,

div.head: THE PLACE OF THE SMALLER NATIONS.
div.p: The Pan-Celtic Congress, which has this week been holding in Edinburgh much learned and curious revelry, is a noteworthy exemplification of that development of racial self-consciousness which has been so widespread a feature of the last half-century. As the progress of material civilisation tends to knit peoples more and more closely together by the improvement of the means of communication and transit, there seems to be a natural reaction of individualism, which causes every smaller racial unit to rally all its resources and assert itself with a newfound enthusiasm and fervour. There is hardly a country in Europe which does not show traces of this racial ferment, working in one guise or another.-"Times,"
WHERE DO THE BIRDS DIE?

The return of the gulls, referred to in this column yesterday, suggests an interesting question. We see them come and go in great flocks in the spring and autumn, and we have them with us all the winter. But how many people, even of those familiar with the great breeding grounds, have ever seem a dead gull whose death could be attributed merely to age 1 Similarly, of the myriads of sparrows in London

-how many are ever seem dead except from violence. And so for the other representatives of far and feather-with, of course, a reservation in respect of game birds and animals, there is a puzzle which few can solve. Where and how do the wild things die ?
